ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: learned basic Portuguese. More importantly, learned a lot about Brazilian culture which is really interesting and not a culture I have a ton of interaction with on a day to day basis. I honestly think I learned more about the culture than the language, so it's a good class on Brazilian culture lol.
Basic introduction to Portuguese

This course has both given me an incredible first semester with a new language and transformed my idea of language as a whole. I learned how to speak conversationally with my peers, have an entertaining dialogue with the professor, and learn about Brazilian society and pop culture.
I developed a strong foundation of Portuguese. Specifically, I learned vocabulary that was essential for me to have conversations with me in Portuguese. I also learned some foundation grammar rules.
learned about portuguese and brazilian culture
I learned about the country of Brazil and about the culture there.
I got a solid foundation in Brazilian Portuguese and learned a lot more about Portuguese music and culture.
I learned how to speak Portuguese at a very basic level, and I also learned a lot about Brazilian culture.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
There was homework every day but it was manageable. The course did feel disorganized at times, like we were jumping from one concept to another. A more specific, detailed syllabus (with specific grammar concepts/vocab themes to be covered each week) might help provide structure for students over the course of the semester. 
The asynchronous day is a gem and one that I hope is kept for future semesters!

Strengths:
-Learning how to hold discussions. The ability to speak came much easier than I expected.
- Manageable workload. I could come to class each day to simply learn rather than worry about taking notes as fast as I could write. 
-Engaging course content.

Weaknesses:
-Asynchronous Wednesdays. The workload was inconsistent and could often take what felt like hours to complete.

I think the course was strategically and efficiently designed to keep students engaged in the course material and in the classroom. The class activities involved partner and group work, which made students work together. 
I think the course could be improved if there was more speaking practice that also involved feedback from the professor. I think a greater emphasis on improving pronunciation would be helpful and is important for an introductory language class.
basic course so it was good

The strength of this course is that in class, the professor always tried to make it fun. The weakness to this class is the organization. The canvas page was beyond confusing and it was unclear which assignments were due which days. It was also difficult to know where we were at with grades because we were never given any indication.

The course was well-organized around central themes and projects. The balance of written assignments to more formal exams felt right, and the organization of a final Portuguese "event" related to the final project was fun and fulfilling. The instructors do a great job of trying to create a sense of community between the different sections of Portuguese. I sometimes wished that the speed of instruction/material could have been a bit quicker, but for the most part the pacing was good, and there were plenty of opportunities to challenge oneself on assignments and out-of-class projects.

With no prior experience to Portuguese, I thought that it was very hard to understand Professor Souza once she started speaking in only Portuguese after the 2nd or 3rd week.  I think that there needs to be a bette blend between English and Portuguese before diving right into speaking solely Portuguese.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES. An interesting language that is very pretty and fun to learn. Not like Spanish at all, so it is refreshing to learning a langugae that I have had very little previous interaction with.
Yes! The department is kind and Portuguese is a beautiful language.
I would strongly recommend the course!

Yes! Portuguese is a very fun language and there is a lot of material that students can use to learn that is very engaging, such as music, podcasts, and videos. I think the Portuguese department at Yale is also very enthusiastic and engaging!
Id say this is a great course for any language requirement, so yes I would recommend it.
yes if you need a good language. definitely take portuguese
Maybe. I only took this course for my language requirement so if they are interested then they should do it.

I would recommend this course to any student who is genuinely interested (or who thinks they might be interested) in learning Portuguese. Don't take this course if you're looking for a gut language course, both because PORT 110 isn't really a gut and (more importantly) because it does a disservice to those in the class who are passionate about the language. Other than that, I think anyone can get a lot from taking this course and learning this language.
Yes, I definitely would recommend this course.  Portuguese is a very fun language and the class was interactive everyday with fun activities to facilitate learning.
